title: Tuesday, 16th May, 2017

BE11:08am

So, FTSE up again.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

And sterling tanked, somewhat

BE11:09am

(Sorry we're going to slow today. The internet's fairly broken.)

BE11:09am

We can get the inflation data out of the way quick, I think, as it's covered in length elsewhere.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

RBC can summarise.

BE11:09am

In April UK CPI inflation was 2.7% y/y, up from 2.3% y/y the previous month. This was above-consensus but in line with the Bank of England staff forecast from last week’s May Inflation Report (and 0.1ppt lower than the RBC forecast). Core CPI inflation rose to 2.4% y/y from 1.8% y/y and RPI inflation jumped to 3.5% y/y from 3.1% y/y. CPIH inflation (with owner-occupiers’ housing costs) rose from 2.3% y/y to 2.6% y/y.

With airfares rising 18.6% y/y, as a result of the timing of Easter, the transport sector made the biggest contribution to the increase in the headline inflation. This was also partly accounted for by changes to vehicle excise duty. Lower petrol prices did provide some offset. In other sectors, higher electricity and clothing prices also explain the move to higher inflation this month. For RPI and CPIH inflation, higher Council Tax bills also made a modest upward contribution.

BE11:10am

Air fares up 18.6% y/y!

11:10 am
BE11:10am

In previous months the pick-up in inflation has been thematically more about goods prices, rather than services (Exhibit 2). However, on this occasion goods price inflation actually moderated from 2.4% y/y to 2.3% y/y whereas services inflation hit 3% y/y (Exhibit 4) for the first time since September 2013. At this stage though, it seems too early to expect that the generally more import-intensive goods sector will have seen the peak impact of pass-through from exchange rate depreciation in 2016 related to the EU referendum. We still see imported inflation being the dominant factor behind above-target inflation for the rest of 2017.

Our takeaway from last week’s May Inflation Report is that, consistent with its mandate, the Bank of England will remain reluctant to bring inflation back down to the 2% target too quickly, for fear of the volatility in output and employment that might also accompany a tightening in policy. Although both we and the Bank expect the inflation rate to fall back towards 2% in 2018, for the next few months it is likely to stay high. We expect a rate of at least 3% y/y at some point before the end of 2017. With pay growth unlikely to match inflation over this period, we remain focused on the plight of the consumer which is set to keep quarterly growth rates roughly around the 0.3% q/q seen in Q1. For now the MPC is in neutral mode, but we continue to see scope for further policy easing in due course, despite above-target inflation.

PM11:10am

Also house prices

PM11:10am

Biggest monthly drop in six years

11:11 am
PM11:11am

None of this particularly feel good

PM11:12am

PM11:12am

That's from Barc -- right click / new tab to read

11:12 am
BE11:12am

(@A. M.: I could dig out that figure but given everyone except the budget airlines hedge most of their burn 18-24 months forward it's not a perfect gauge of anything much. Plus you have the trade of cheaper fuel driving down ticket prices as it keeps marginally profitable planes in the air.)

BE11:13am

Can't see a lot of comment on the Land Registry data. Isn't it usually the lagging indicator here?

BE11:14am

Here's Howard Archer, who we've not quoted in a while.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

March’s drop house prices reported by the Office for National Statistics/ Land Registry add to a mounting collection of weaker data and surveys which point to the housing market being increasingly affected by the deepening squeeze on consumers and their concerns over the outlook. This includes both the Halifax and the Nationwide reporting that house prices dipped in April and the Bank of England reporting mortgage approvals at a six-month low in March.

We suspect markedly weakening consumer fundamentals, likely mounting caution over making major spending decisions, and elevated house price to earnings ratios will weigh down further on housing market activity and house prices over the coming months. However, a shortage of supply is likely to put a floor under prices.

Consequently, we believe house price gains over 2017 will be limited to 2.0% - and there is a very real and mounting possibility that it could come in lower than that. However, we doubt that June’s General Election is unlikely to materially affect the housing market.

SUMMARY

· The house price index produced by the Office for National Statistics showed UK house prices falling 0.6% month-on-month in March. The year-on-year increase in house prices dipped to 4.1% in March after rising back up to 5.6% in February from 5.0% in January. It is down from a peak of 9.3% in June 2016 (the highest since October 2014).
· Furthermore, data for April from both the Halifax and the Nationwide showed house prices dipping month-on-month resulting in the annual rate falling to the lowest level since the first half of 2013.
· The recent softness in house prices comes amid evidence that housing market activity is stuttering. The Bank of England reported that mortgage approvals for house purchases dipped to a six-month low in March.
· The data fuel our belief that housing market activity and prices are being pressurized by deteriorating consumer fundamentals and softer confidence. We expect these pressures to intensify over the coming month.
· Consequently, we believe that house price gains over 2017 will be limited to 2.0% - and there is a very real and mounting possibility that it could come in lower than that.
· We expect the fundamentals for house buyers to progressively deteriorate over the coming months with consumers’ purchasing power weakening further and the labour market likely softening. Increasing economic uncertainty is also likely to weigh down on consumer confidence and willingness to engage in major transactions such as buying a house. Housing market activity and prices are also likely to be pressurized by stretched house prices to earnings ratios and tight checking of prospective mortgage borrowers by lenders
· However, the downside for house prices should be limited markedly by a shortage of houses for sale. Ongoing very low mortgage interest rates should also help the housing market.

BE11:15am

Speaking of airlines and/or sandwiches .....

11:15 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,243, down 67 (-5.11%), High: 1,271, Low: 1,221, Volume: 3.49m
BE11:15am

It does both, of course, and makes better margin on the latter than the former.

BE11:16am

H1 shows pricing still under pressure, which is somewhat contrary to the inflation data.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

H1 underlying loss before tax of £212m, which is worse than a consensus of £200m-ish.

BE11:17am

Yields weak even excluding the Easter timing thing.

BE11:17am

Guidance uninspiring. Here are Barclays' bullet points.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

The initial summer trading outlook for RPS down low single digit in Q3, and likely mid single digit in Q4, is in line with sellside forecasts but probably behind buyside expectations, following the stock’s strong run over the last two months.

Mechanically, the moving parts of easyJet’s updated outlook imply FY PBT roughly inline with consensus (£367m), as small improvements in FX (£5m) and fuel guidance (£10m) compensate for the H1 miss.

The updated fleet plan sees easyJet starting to take 235-seat A321neos next year, a welcome benefit for unit costs, but with a slightly smaller aircraft count: such that we think the medium term growth rate of 7-8% is unchanged.

PM11:18am

Is this another one where Liberum have a v aggressive 'sell' target price?

PM11:18am

I think it is

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Gerald Khoo

BE11:19am

It is! 50% downside or thereabouts.

PM11:19am

825p target

11:19 am
PM11:19am

H1 was always going to be challenging, given Easter timing and FX headwinds, and it has been a touch worse than expected. RPS fell by 9.7% constant currency, at the worse end of guidance. Forward bookings appear encouraging (c.5 points better YoY for H2). The H2 environment appears less challenging than H1, with Q3 RPS seen down long single digits, but management sees FY PBT in line with current consensus, despite better fuel and FX guidance. The current premium valuation is pricing in earnings upgrades, which are not coming through at present.

PM11:19am

On our current published estimates, easyJet trades on a September 2017E P/E of 17.6x and EV/EBITDAR of 9.0x. This is a material premium to Ryanair in P/E terms and in line in EV/EBITDAR terms. We struggle to justify this valuation given Ryanair's superior track record, higher ROIC and earnings growth. In our view, easyJet's premium rating is pricing in a substantial upgrade to current year estimates. In turn, the premium to Ryanair suggests the source of this upgrade must be specific to easyJet (i.e. not an industry issue that helps Ryanair's earnings too). We remain to be convinced such a catalyst will be forthcoming.

BE11:20am

It's not easy to find a buyer of EasyJet, actually.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

RBC also selling.

BE11:20am

Our view – at the profit nadir, so will momentum turn? Key to us is the cost progress in H1. With a PBT loss of £236m (including AOC and SLB costs) and £212m before one-off items vs PY H1 £24m loss on unit revenues down 4.9% YoY (down 9.7% underlying vs. end Q1 outlook of ‘down by high single digits’ underlying, with Easter timing accounting for 240bpts of the YoY change), on (ex FX) unit costs ex fuel up flat (vs. company expectations +1%) we see a growing chance profitability might have reached its nadir – with forward bookings ahead of PY H2 and the company ‘seeing an improving revenue per seat trend as well as the continued reduction of competitor capacity growth.’Q3 unit revenues are seen down low single digits, with Q4 likely to be helped by lessening competitor growth.

BE11:21am

Even UBS, which was a buyer, says .....

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Although earnings base looks to have formed, we note recent share price strength. We place our rating and price target Under Review.

BE11:22am

Canaccord?

BE11:22am

Headline interim pre-tax loss rose to £-212m, primarily driven by a weak revenue environment, Easter falling in H2 (c.45m negative impact) and negative net currency impact (£82m). Excluding the Easter and currency effect, PBT loss would have been c.£85m. The significant increase in competition that easyJet has experienced on its network in recent years is, in our view, likely to continue, and the resulting yield pressure is likely to hold back earnings.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Nope.

BE11:22am

Davy's on underperform. Og wait, is Goodbody still positive?

BE11:23am

Overall, we would read the release as a positive for sentiment but would caution that current valuations are ahead of events as one has to look to FY19 to justify the current share price on long-term multiples.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Nope.

PM11:23am

hehehe

BE11:23am

On the negative front, ex-fuel cost guidance for year remains at +1%, with this suggesting a deteriorating trend in the current half. Additionally, reorganisation costs have also been mentioned for this year and next. Finally, the AOC application is delayed. Last quarter, easyJet had said they would submit the application in calendar Q117 and expected and approval by mid-year. This timetable has now slipped to Q4 and suggests that the application may have faced tougher EU resistance than had been expected.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

If the flacks want to send me anyone who's positive on Easyjet, please go ahead. Genuinely, I'm seeking to provide balance but coming up empty.

undefined
BE11:25am

May as well get Vodafone out of the way as well.

11:24 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 219.67, up 8.56 (+4.06%), High: 220.40, Low: 215.70, Volume: 74.42m
BE11:25am

One of those "headlines terrible, shares up" things.

BE11:25am

Results missed.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

But the numbers are now reported ex India, and they are fine! 2018 guidance is a bit better than hoped, in fact.

BE11:26am

Suggesting the divi might be covered by next year! It hasn't been covered in basically forever.

BE11:26am

So ignore that India is -11.5% YoY

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Also ignore that the UK's still pretty weak -- perhaps because all the staff know they'll be working for Malone sooner or later.

BE11:27am

Ignore that Italy's deteriorating due to Iliad cutting prices.

BE11:28am

Focus instead on Vodafone successfully keeping a lid on costs to offset a lack of actual operational improvement in about two-thirds of its markets.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Here's Barclays, with a wall of numbers.

BE11:28am

Vodafone has reported a 2H17 result with profitability ahead of expectations in the new “ex India” format. 4Q service revenues were in line with our and company consensus at +1.5% in 4Q (3Q:+2.1%, 2Q: +2.0%), with UK below (Enterprise) and Germany ahead. 2H EBITDA was €7.1bn, +6.3% organic in 2H17 (Absolute number excludes India, organic calc does also). The company cites a €300m net opex reduction in the year (i.e. net cost cutting not gross). As such absolute EBITDA was +3.6%/€250m ahead of our expectations in 2H, but this includes additional shareholder recharges (India) of ca€100m. FCF was €4.1bn (€4.3bn on a guidance basis), slightly ahead of guidance due to higher EBITDA. India service revenues (now excluded from reported financials) were -11.5% vs our -9% estimate, and EBITDA was 14% below our forecast, giving FY17 EBITDA (per 3-6% FY17 growth at just 3.4%, the lower end of expectations). For FY18, the company is indicating EBITDA of €14-14.5bn, well ahead of consensus of €13.8bn (Barc: €13.9bn). However this does include €300m of handset financing, and an additional €100m of India shareholder recharges. FCF is expected to be c. €5bn (Barc: €4.8bn, cons: €4.7bn, no handset financing impact), and the DPS is expected to grow (was +2% in 2H).

BE11:29am

And here's Jefferies, who add a few carriage returns.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Strong cost reduction supported accel EBITDA growth in 2H16/17, bringing FY in 2.5% ahead of cons. VOD confidently guides to FY17/18 EBITDA of €14.0-14.5bn (cons €13.8bn) and for FCF around €5.0bn (cons €4.7bn). On this basis, VOD reasserts its intention to grow DPS annually (cons has DPS flat), a message that might be seen as contrasting against BT's more hesitant outlook last week. Weak UK results may cast doubt on its longevity to / necessity for the Group.

BE11:29am

FY16/17 ahead. Strong net cost reduction (-€0.3bn y/y) supported an acceleration in EBITDA growth (ex-India) to +6.3% in 2H16/17 (+5.2% 1H16/17) and brought FY EBITDA in at €14.15bn (€13.80bn cons). On the guidance basis (incl. India), FY16/17 EBITDA was €5.8bn (guidance €15.7-16.1bn, cons €15.7bn) and FCF was €4.3bn (guidance at least €4.0bn, cons €4.1bn). For the FY, VOD held tech costs flat and reduced commercial and support costs. Nonetheless, commercial momentum was robust ex-UK and India. Organic service revs (ex-India) +1.5% y/y in 4Q16/17, which was in line with cons, with Italy/Turkey both +40bp ahead but the UK -70bp below. Adj for specific h/winds this quarter (guided at -80bp), Group service revs (ex-India) were in line with 3Q16/17 (+2.2% y/y). For India, service rev decline accel to -11.5% (cons -10.0%) from -1.9% 3Q / +5.4% 2Q. Other key figures (with India deconsolidated): FY16/17 Group revs €14.63bn (cons €14.82bn), EBITDA €14.15bn (cons €13.80bn), FCF €4.06bn (cons €3.70bn), net debt €31.2bn (cons €31.1bn).

BE11:29am

FY17/18 outlook. VOD confidently guides for 4%-8% EBITDA growth, implying a range of €14.0-14.5bn, well ahead of cons (flat y/y at €13.8bn). FCF guidance is around €5bn (cons €4.7bn). On this basis, VOD reasserts its intention to grow DPS annually (cons has DPS flat), a message that might be seen as contrasting against BT's more hesitant outlook last week. FY17/18 EBITDA guidance implies y/y growth of €0.5-1.0bn against an adjusted FY16/17 base of €13.5bn (which is derived from the reported €14.15bn by deducting NL's 1Q-3Q16/17 €0.5bn EBITDA contribution before deconsolidation and an FX benefit of €0.2bn). In FY17/18, VOD anticipates that a €0.3bn y/y EBITDA benefit from UK handset financing will be offset by an equivalent loss of roaming profit. EBITDA growth guidance envisages that operating costs will once again be brought down y/y in net terms. Brand/mgmt. fees from India/NL are expected to be stable y/y.

11:29 am
PM11:30am

So we are just going to ignore Voda India going forward?

BE11:30am

Vodafone intends to, so it seems fair enough for us to as well.

PM11:30am

Bar some fresh, random tax hit

11:30 am
PM11:30am

But i'll go along with that

BE11:30am

(@OJatHome: I'm very old.)

11:31 am
PM11:31am

CYBG mentioned repeatedly on the right

PM11:31am

Interims here http://www.investe...1705160700091995F/

BE11:31am

H1 miss. Fairly straightforward.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Price whacked

BE11:32am

Operating income stagnating.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Impairments at possibly unsustainable levels of lowness.

BE11:33am

Here's Shore.

BE11:33am

· Adj PBT increased by 15% to £123m, representing 46% of our full year forecast of £266m. Mortgage loan book growth was 5% and core SME was 3%. NIM of 226bps was stable on the prior year outcome but an improvement on Q1 of 222bps implying c230bps in Q2. However the impairment ratio of 15bps implied c24bps in Q2 having been just 6bps in Q1. Underlying costs reduced by £5m to £348m as the group continues to drive through efficiency improvements. The underlying RoTE improved by 1.8ppts yoy to 6.3%, but remains well below any reasonable estimate of the CoE (c10%).

· Statutory PBT of £46m was stated after £53m of restructuring charges, £5m of separation costs and £19m of conduct charges. This is disappointing, in our view.

· No interim dividend was declared, albeit the group is still targeting commencement of dividend payments for the full year.

· TNAVPS was broadly unchanged during H1 at 283p.

· The core tier 1 ratio dipped by 0.1ppts during Q1 to 12.5%, being the mid-point of the group’s 12-13% target range.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Full year guidance appears to be unchanged from that provided at the full year results in November, with management anticipating mid-single digit loan book growth, a broadly stable NIM, costs in the range £690m-£700m and a CET1 ratio comfortably within the 12-13% range. Consequently we do not anticipate making material changes to our full year earnings estimates, albeit this does require underlying performance to improve in H2.

For y/e Sep ’17 we forecast adj PBT of £266m, adj dil EPS of 18.9p, DPS of 3.8p and TNAVPS of 297p. At yesterday’s closing price of 290p and based on our current forecasts, CYBG trades on a PER of 15.3x (dropping to 13.4x in Sep ’18), dividend yield of 1.3% (pay-out ratio of 20%) and P/TNAV of 1.0x (RoTE of 6.5%).

On near-term valuation multiples CYBG shares look expensive given current weak returns. However, this ignores management targets for further technology driven cost efficiency improvements and the release of surplus capital through an anticipated move to IRB risk weight calculations (versus the current standardised approach) for the mortgage book. However, even though we expect successful delivery against such targets, we still see 3% downside to our fair value of 280p. The shares therefore remain a weak HOLD at best.

BE11:34am

And Numis.

BE11:34am

We remain concerned that a normalisation of impairments, rising
competition and Brexit uncertainty will make it difficult for CYBG to achieve its 2019 target of “double digit” RoTE. While there is still significant room for improvement, we maintain our SELL recommendation as we do not believe the high level of execution risk associated with such a transformation and the Group's below average profitability (2018E 5.5%) is fairly reflected in the Group's current valuation of 1.0x 2018E TNAV.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Think Goodbody have started covering the challengers...

PM11:34am

John Cronin

BE11:34am

Thumbs up

11:34 am
PM11:34am

NIM better but net interest income behind our expectations

While NIM came in at 226bps in H1 (we were looking for 224bps), representing an

improvement in the 222bps reported in Q1, the beat was driven by lower average

interest-earning assets (due to a lower quantum of liquid assets). The average asset

yield on the mortgages book of 2.96% was significantly behind our expectations for

3.11% (we were in line on other asset yields) though we would note that this is

likely to mean that the pace of compression in H2 should be less than we have

forecast. As a result, CYBG posted net interest income of £411m, below both our

own forecasts (£435m) and consensus forecasts. This is the main reason for the

delta between our forecast for underlying PBT of £161m and the £123m outturn –

though we were slightly lower on recurring operating costs (£348m outturn versus

our £337m).

PM11:35am

Sorry for the formatting

PM11:35am

Net loans growth in line with our expectations; deposits lower

Net loans came in at £29.9bn, marginally ahead of our expectations for £29.8bn.

This reflects annualised growth of 5% in mortgage balances to £22.4bn and 3%

annualised growth in SME lending, which is encouraging following the high level of

redemptions reported in the SME book in Q1. While CYBG achieved 4.5% growth in

current account balances in the period, overall customer deposits reduced by

c.£700m in the six-month period to £26.4bn, behind our expectations for marginal

growth of £200m – as management acted to reduce corporate deposit volumes.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Sorry again

PM11:35am

We can't have this John!

BE11:36am

(@wayneJ: I'm not sure Gary Greenwood of Shore can be accused of being London-centric, given I seem to remember he lives in Eccleston.)

11:36 am
PM11:36am

The delta on the underlying PBT along with the higher one-off costs means that the CET1 ratio came in at 12.5% (12.6% at end-Q1), below our expectations for 12.9%. In overall terms, despite the mild disappointment, the story is still intact. CYBG is very much still a restructuring play following years of underinvestment in the business on the part of NAB and we expect to see CET1 capital progression owing to loan growth and continued cost reduction in the coming years –with other benefits to accrue from migration to IRB credit risk modelling and efficiencies owing to the digital investment.

PM11:36am

That's better (different pdf version...)

undefined
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Elsewhere!

BE11:37am

United Utilities etc slump! on the nationalisation threat.

United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 1,011, down 15 (-1.46%), High: 1,013, Low: 999.00, Volume: 648.15k
11:37 am
BE11:37am

That's UU's slumping! by a bit more than a percent.

BE11:37am

Severn similar.

Severn Trent PLC (SVT:LSE): Last: 2,399, down 30 (-1.24%), High: 2,408, Low: 2,394, Volume: 338.11k
11:38 am
BE11:38am

... which we could blame on Deutsche Bank downgrading.

BE11:38am

Or we could blame it on nationalisation fears, via this neat equity-for-debt swap thing the Labour types were talking about on the radio this morning.

BE11:39am

Not sure how that'd work in practice -- and it's an obvious point to make that we'll almost certainly never find out.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Deutsche, meanwhile, goes against the sector on valuation.

BE11:40am

UK water stocks have built on almost a decade long bull run with further rises in share prices this year. Based on current returns the three UK waters still look attractive. However, we believe that cuts at the 2019 price review will come into focus by the end of the year. In this report we take an early look at the review and the implications for the stocks using our returns based framework. Our analysis suggests that Severn Trent & United Utilities now look fair value and we downgrade to Hold. Pennon remains a Buy partly because we believe there may be scope for it to reassure on the performance of Viridor at its results.

BE11:40am

Although we are not yet half way through the current 2015-20 review period, the 2019 review, which will set prices over 2020-25, will start to come into focus. We believe that the political context for this review is different from the last, with more focus on affordability. Given that current regulation looks generous we forecast that returns will be cut back meaningfully and expect this to become clearer when OFWAT publishes its final framework proposals in December 2017. The three listed companies are likely to be insulated partly by low borrowing costs and outperformance under incentive schemes, although we forecast a cut to average book value equity returns from over 13% p.a. currently to c.11% p.a. after the review.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

If current returns were sustainable the UK waters would still look very attractive, on an absolute basis and in comparison to the European pure play network peer group. However, we believe the UK stocks are more vulnerable to return cuts than the continental grids and we expect the waters to look closer to fair value after the review. We forecast regulatory earnings yields for Severn Trent & United Utilities of 6.3% p.a. post review – in-line with their cost of equity – and 6.6% for Pennon (down from 7-7.5% currently).

BE11:40am

There have been very high multiples paid for a number of European and UK Regulated Asset Base transactions over the last year and bid risk remains for the UK waters. On the downside it is possible that investors overreact to signalled return cuts or start to worry about dividend cuts if the review process starts to look tougher than expected. Changes in bond yields and inflation are also key risk factors for the sector.

BE11:40am

We have increased our price targets for the three UK waters slightly, rolling our RAB based valuations over a year to March 2018, reducing our estimate for the cost of equity slightly, but factoring in tougher cuts to returns from 2020. Severn Trent and United Utilities now look fair value in our view and we cut from Buy to Hold. Pennon’s shares have risen this year, although there has been a lot of negativity towards its waste business, Viridor. Some of this is understandable although we believe it may have masked the positives, including a pickup in waste market conditions. While there are upside and downside risks we think that the positives are likely to come through at next week’s results.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

........ which covers all the usual bases.

BE11:42am

And in case you're wondering ....

BE11:42am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

47 pages. Not a mention.

undefined
PM11:43am

Hey Inmarsat has got another satellite up in the sky

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The Inmarsat-5 F4 satellite, no less.

PM11:43am

Inmarsat-5 F4 (I-5 F4) was launched by SpaceX on a Falcon 9 rocket at 00:21 (BST) 19:21 (ET) from the historic launch pad 39A at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Following satellite separation at 00:53 (BST) 19:53 ET, we acquired telemetry from our Perth ground station at 01:04 BST / 20:04 ET.

BE11:48am

Last night Inmarsat’s I5-F4 satellite was successfully launch aboard a SpaceX rocket from the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida. Initially when the option to build the fourth Global Xpress (GX) satellite was exercised back in 2013 it was intended to be a ground spare, providing back-up capacity in case there was a launch issue/in-orbit issue with the three primary satellites. However with the global network up and running Inmarsat has developed an incremental business case for the fourth satellite and this should provide capacity/revenue upside.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Inmarsat has reiterated on a number of occasions that revenues from the fourth GX satellite will be incremental to the medium-term target: GX revenues of a run rate of $500m per annum by the end of 2020 from the initial three satellites. There still remains uncertainty as to, ultimate location, customer, functionality and ramp-up timing and thus it is difficult to attribute any immediate value to the fourth satellite, but on a simplistic basis one could think of c$160m annualized revenues.

BE11:48am

Inmarsat has yet to announce the customer/s on the fourth satellite, and although there was disappointment from some at the Q1 results two weeks ago that no announcement was made, Inmarsat did state there are many different options they can pursue. We think potential uses could be in high traffic areas, similar to the European Aviation Network (EAN) satellite over Europe thus providing capacity for in-flight connectivity; alternatively it could be used for special missions which is high margin.

BE11:48am

Given the global Ka-band network functions with the original three GX satellites, Inmarsat has the flexibility to pursue various growth opportunities with the fourth. This fourth satellite helps to drive the long-term upside potential at Inmarsat and although we acknowledge visibility is limited we think there are exciting avenues that can deliver incremental growth. Reiterate BUY.

BE11:53am

Here's Berenberg.

BE11:53am

Countryside is a listed UK housebuilder with two principal divisions: 1) Housebuilding, which offers more and faster growth than many listed peers; and 2) Partnerships, which works with local authorities and housing associations to regenerate public land that often has below-standard housing already on it. We see several areas for growth. It is currently the second-smallest listed housebuilder with the landbank, pipeline and capital in place for a larger business. In Partnerships, we see a growing need for social housing and the division is likely to be far less cyclical than “normal” housebuilding. Management is currently reviewing its five-year targets, and we expect a significant increase in ambition. We initiate with a Buy recommendation and 330p price target.

BE11:53am

● Partnerships division is differentiated with high returns and less cyclicality than “normal” housebuilding: The Partnerships business is able to negotiate attractive payment terms, and we believe it is significantly less cyclical than mainstream housebuilding. It had a ROCE of 70% in 2016 and a sustainable ROCE of c50%, around double that of the average housebuilder. We see sufficient barriers to entry to suggest these returns are sustainable. With 8,000 plots in its landbank, a further 6,000 on which it is the preferred bidder, and visibility on a further 35,000 plots to bid on, we expect our 2,197 completions for 2017E will be built upon in subsequent years. With net cash and a £300m bank facility to cover peak net debt of c£130m, Countryside is well capitalised to fund its growth trajectory.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

● Housebuilding well placed to deliver continued growth in the current market: We expect a c75% jump in operating profit in 2017 on sales that are up 20% and completions that are up 22%. Further indicators of growth include that one-quarter of our expected 2017 sales are covered by forward orders, directly owned landbanks cover six years of housebuilding, while the strategic landbank increases this to 19 years. Reservation rates remain strong at c0.89/site/week as the number of active sites has increased to 48 from an average of 36 in 2016. The move down the ASP curve supports growth and its push for a 200bp improvement in the gross profit margin to 24%, in our view.

BE11:54am

● Valuation undemanding and trading at an unjustified discount: Despite returns above the sector average, Countryside trades at a 20% P/E discount. We think that is unjustified and expect the shares to perform as the greater profits are reported through 2017. We expect management to report new medium-term targets with H1 results on 17 May 2017, with both those and the reported results as potential catalysts for the share price.

BE12:01pm

Here's RBC to summarise what's happening here.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Our view: BHP appears to be pivoting to growth with Spence expansion set for a decision in August, continued studies on Olympic Dam and an ongoing phased development of Jansen. BHP states it can add 20% to its production with a $5bn investment. Management will also assess asset sales and swaps in its US onshore business. With a declining production profile vs. peers, we think this is a logical next step, however this will temper the near-term free cash flow at a time when peers like RIO and GLEN are potentially going to see significantly increased cash returns. Andrew Mackenzie will be presenting in Barcelona at 8am BST.

Additionally, Elliott is back with a new presentation and letter, criticising the BHP response to its initial letter as misleading. The revised set of proposals will allow BHP to remain an Australian company while still unwinding the DLC structure. Elliott is calling for an immediate formal review of the entire petroleum business.

Momentum around the Elliott push had faded following BHP's initial rejection of breaking up the DLC as too costly and risky. The timing of this letter coincides with a competitor's mining conference in Barcelona which should keep this issue at the forefront of Investor conversations. As we wrote two weeks ago, we see the US onshore business ‎as providing a distraction and the procyclical spend erodes value elsewhere. We do see benefit through the cycle for BHP's wider petroleum business and the ability to invest counter-cyclically into Tier I assets, however there will require substantial spend in the coming years to maintain volumes and returns. Although the investor activism is welcome as it helps to provide focus on potential areas of value, we do not expect this will, in isolation, result to material changes in BHP's strategy in the immediate term. We remain constructive on the sector and continue to prefer RIO, GLEN and AAL in the diversified space.
